My husband and I adored this dish on our trip to Rome a few years ago and have a definite soft spot for it. An extremely simple pasta, it basically just involves cheese and pe

Wow wow wow.


I came here after a bad experience at another restaurant and this place blew my mind.

Every dish we had was simply amazing.

We had

The octopus - so tender and the pesto was phenomenal.

The beef carpaccio - a religious experience for me. The mushrooms were cured somehow and have changed how I think about em.

The roasted squash - never knew you could make squash taste that amazing.

The papardelle - a bit too al dente for my taste, but you could really see the taste and effort they've put into this dish and I really appreciate that.

The tiramisu - just look at the photo.

A boulevardier - really well done.


The location has a small entrance but you walk in and it's actually quite large. The servers all seemed really happy and relaxed working there.

And final plus - the washrooms had product from malin and gootze which I first tried in a hotel in Istanbul and fell in love. Havent seen it anywhere else and so happy to see it here.

This is officially my fav Italian spot in TO.

This restaurant is now on the top 10 list for the best restaurants in Canada.  I came here before the list came out and I have to say I am extremely underwhelmed.  There are much better restaurants in Toronto that deserve to take its place on the list, and especially much better ITALIAN in Toronto.

I had the calamari to start which was fresh and came with some shishito peppers which was fun.  But I find nowadays calamari is pretty good at most places.  For the mains I had the ravioli (cello spinach, stracciatella, walnut pesto) which is not a dish that would bring me back to the restaurant again.  I found the walnut pesto to be overpowering and very gritty/thick, but to be fair I actually don't like walnut that much.  

The pizza I had was thin crust and just nothing amazing.  There is MUCH better pizza elsewhere all over Toronto.  I have NO idea how this restaurant made it to the top restaurant list in Canada and I will not be coming back again.  I am giving 3 stars because the service is FANtastic and the restaurant is beautiful.

This restaurant was recently voted as one of the top restaurants in Canada for 2019 - they are actually number 9 on the list. Anyone who knows me, knows how much I love Italian food, so I was really excited to try this place out. 

There were 7 of us at the table, and we discussed the possibility of having the family style meal, which is usually recommended for a party of our size. However, it wasn't easy getting everyone to agree on which dishes to try, so we all ended up ordering our own dishes. A couple of us did share a few bites, so I was able to taste a few more dishes than what I ordered for myself. This is always my favourite way to dine, so you can experience as much of the menu as possible. 

Our server did say that the menu changes with the seasons, which is great since you get the freshest ingredients at their peak. It can also mean that a favourite dish won't always be available, but it's great to try new things. 

I started out with a Negroni cocktail, which was probably the best one I've ever had. Kudos to the bartender, as it was perfection. For a starter, I had the grilled octopus - I was actually hoping it was available as an entrée, as I'd seen photos of it already. Sadly for me, it was just appetizer size. It wasn't as tender as I'd hoped, but it was really flavorful and well-seasoned. For my entrée, I had the branzino, which was served whole. It was difficult to eat because there were so many bones, and it tasted a bit overdone, but still enjoyable. I shared some of my fish with a fellow diner in exchange for a few pieces of his pork chop, which was exceptional. We also shared a side of asparagus as well as the cauliflower, the latter being a bit bland. Their namesake pizza was a big hit, with lots of pistachios and a hint of smoked cheese. 

Four of us ordered desserts, which we shared with each other, and I have to say that the lemon crostata that I ordered was very good, but the Italian custard, called Bonet PIemontese, was the standout for everyone. It's very much like a crème caramel in both appearance and texture. I would definitely order this again. Their coffee was also exceptional, although we did not get it until after we'd all finished our desserts. They really need to improve the timing on that, as most people prefer to have their coffee with their dessert. 

Service was generally quite good, although we did wait quite a while to order our food, and then again had about a 35 minute wait between the appetizers and the entrées. When they brought the bill, they advised us that they were unable to split by seat. This is usually an awkward situation, but it was made even worse by the fact that many of the items on the bill were listed in Italian, so some people were unsure of what they had ordered. It took about 25 minutes just to sort it out. I cannot understand with technology today, why the restaurant cannot split a bill. Their POS system was one of the newest and fanciest ones I've ever seen, so I'm not sure if I believe they can't do it, rather than they choose not to. 

In any case, the food was definitely good enough that I want to return, next time to try the pasta, as not one person in the group ordered any on this visit.

SERVICE:
The service was welcoming, friendly, and attentive. Our server checked up on us often and refilled our water frequently. 

FOOD:
Beef tartare - Loved this! I highly recommend

Calamari - this was very average. I would recommend skipping this and order another appetizer. 

Seafood pasta - this is one of their popular dishes. The sauce was on the lighter side but it was still tasty. Noodles were cooked perfectly.   

Carbonara - this was a daily special and it was well executed. We absolutely loved this!

OVERALL:
I had an enjoyable dining experience here and I will most likely return.

Oh my god. This place was amazing in every aspect. I came here on a Wednesday night with my coworker and we were aware of the positive reviews but this totally exceeded my expectations. It was pretty busy and we didn't have a reservation so we were seated at the bar. I didn't mind, and the service at the bar was actually phenomenal. Very attentive and friendly. They took time to wipe our table between courses and ensured our drinks were never empty.

We shared the polpo e fagiolli (grilled octopus, cannellini beans and salsa verde) and cavolgiore in paedella (cauliflower, sultana raisins, garlic, lemon and parsley) to start. The latter dish is actually a side but we had it as an appetizer. The octopus, which came highly recommended by the staff was cooked to perfection. It has a nice amount of char to it and was very crispy. The cauliflower was good too - an interesting combination with the raisins but it worked!

For the main, I got the reginelle pappardelle (slow cooked oxtail ragu, pangratto, parsley and parmigiano reggiano). It was soo tasty. There was a good amount of oxtail, and the flavours were all there. There was a crispy layer of breadcrumbs and cheese and it added a bit of texture to every bite. Loved this dish so much.

For dessert we shared the lemon crostata (lemon meringue with candied rosemary) and bonet piemontese (italian custard with amaretto, coffee and vanilla). Nothing but good things to say about both of these dishes!

Ok, let's get this out of the way: I have no idea why this is the 9th best restaurant in Canada in 2019, and you'll be massively disappointed if you expect it to be. Checking for expectations though, it's good. We managed to grab an early dinner slot and got:
- Pulpo e Fagioli: The octopus was really tender, you could cut through it easily with the typical blunt table knife. The swipe of salsa verde and the bed of cannellini beans didn't add much flavour though.
- La Giulietta: Their signature pizza was definitely worthy of their name. This will sound weird, but my favourite part was how good the dough was - thin yet not limp, great taste but not distracting to the toppings, held everything together well. Also, never had pistachios on pizza before and thought this was a great.
- Pappardelle al Ragu: The oxtail was melt-in-your-mouth amazing, though was let down by the pedestrian tomato sauce and a-bit-too-aldente pasta noodles.
- Fogo Island Cioppino: Kinda like an Italian bouillabaisse. Good flavour, though not enough seafood (cod, mussels, shrimp) for my liking.
- Dessert: Got the Red Fife Tiramisu and Gelato del Giorno, and both were winners. The tiramisu had a nice thick custard that made it a bit different. The seasonal soft serve gelato that day was chamomile, which, drizzled with honey, was just a perfect way to end the meal.

The prices were expectedly high, the place had a nice upscale hip vibe, the servers were tremendous, though the pacing of the meal was a bit too slow for me. Overall, Giulietta provided a good dining experience. Not 9th best, maybe not even 99th best. But there were enough hits to make it a worthwhile try.

4 stars overall. It was a good dining experience though not sure if I'll be back.

5 stars for the La Giulietta pizza, tiramisu and soft serve. All of them tasted amazing. Also, kudos to the great service and decor.

4 stars for the octopus. It was well cooked and really tasty, though not the best I've had.

3.5 stars for the cioppino since there wasn't enough seafood. 3 stars for the pappardelle rage since it wasn't as tasty as it could have been.

Hands down one of my favourite Italian places in the city! This isn't your typical rustic Italian joint. Its clean and modern decor doesn't just feel Italian, but classy and upscale.

We decided to family style everything so we all got to try a bit of something. To start, we had the fried calamari, lamb sausage, octopus, and fried fior di latte. Hard to choose a favourite, but I think it'd have to be the octopus and lamb sausage. The octopus comes beautifully whole with a light pesto sauce over some beans. It was tender and crunchy at the same time. The sausage was packed with juices and flavour. One bite leaves you wanting more.

For mains, we shared the special - a squid ink tagliatelle, the parpadelle, the seafood pasta, and the pecoroni and cheese pasta. All were amazing, but my favourites were the special and the parpadelle. Each was so unique and represented such different flavours from its other menu items. That's what made it so good. Each one was so tasty.

Finally, to end the night, we shared the wildflower tart, lemon tart, and the salted chocolate hazelnut cake. Man, what a way to end the night! I would highly recommend all three, but the wildflower tart and the chocolate cake were amazing. The wildflower tart was really unique. It brought a really light flavour, but the chocolate cake was wonderfully dark and rich. When the salted chocolate hits your tongue, you're in love.

I cannot wait to come again!

Nice selection of wines and the sommelier was super helpful! 
We got their Giulietta pizza and it was great. Also, loved their Brussel sprouts, lightly charred on one side and served with sliced almonds. Their pasta special for the night was a triangle ravioli and they were delicious. 
The octopus was tender but too salty in my opinion, too bad because we love a good octopus dish! 
They also had a burrata with speck on toast appetizer special, it was tasty but very difficult to share among 4 people. The other comment I have with most of their dishes is for an establishment that recommends sharing plates for the table, many cannot be conveniently shared. ( the burrata, the pepe long Roman pasta, the octopus wasn't pre -cut)
We had a nice time.

Overall: 5
Possibly my favourite Italian restaurant in Toronto.

Food: 5
Ambiance/Decor: 5
Service: 5
 
I have been here a couple of times now and it's one of my go to places when someone comes back to visit. The house made pastas here are amazing and cooked perfectly. Pizza is baked in a wood fired oven with perfectly thin crust. 

For appetizers I usually go for the Calamari or the Polpo e Fagioli, the octopus is sous vide for 3 hours then charred in the oven and is absolutely delicious. For pastas, you can't really go wrong with any of them. I've had the Cacio e Pepe, Oxtail Ragu, the seafood pasta, and the chestnut agnolotti. I loved all of them and can't really pick a favorite. My favourite red pizza is the L'Amentea, the soppressata adds a nice savoury flavour and a slight kick. If you prefer white pizzas, La Giulietta on the other hand is beautiful and decadent. Desserts here are also great, sweet but not overly decadent. The Torta della Nonna, Bigne al Pistachio, and the house made gelato are all great choices.  

The restaurant has seating at the bar, standard tables, and chef's table. If you don't mind it being a bit louder the chef's table is great and they brought us complimentary cheese spread to start.

Part of a longer review...

"With Giulietta, Chef Rob Rossi envisioned light yet traditional Italian cuisine. The menu was distilled down to essentials made for partager avec vos amis, starring house-made pasta, wood-fired pizza and simple but thoughtful proteins and vegetable sides.

We ordered everything just as it was meant to be eaten -- shared. The polpo e fagioli ($24) and finocchio e arancia ($16) arrived first, which we politely demolished with gusto. Pour moi, octopus is always un plat préféré, and this version was perfectly tender and charred. Naked cannellini beans and salsa verde brought some texture and spice to the dish, but not in an overwhelming manner. This was a star dish and was portion-appropriate to whet the palate before the pièces de résistance.

A testament to authentic Italian cuisine is usually in the quality of the pizza and the pasta. La pizza est bonne-- with six kinds on the menu (like La Giulietta ($22) with Sicilian pistachio, lardo di Modena, panna and smoked scamorza), all with a chewy, bubbly crust that is crisp to the bite. We ordered the more traditional L'Amentea ($21), a doughy canvas that featured light tomato sauce and a punchy kick from soppressata and garlic in every bite. It was harmonized by fior di latte and Sicilian oregano. Delicious, for certain, but nothing très original."

Some hits and many misses; 
Always sad when slow/ inattentive or simply bad service ruins great dishes. However, the setting, the space, and the wine list are great. 

The food: although executed greatly leaves something to be desired in flavour. Simple ingredients are supposed to speak for themselves here mostly, however more "cooked" dishes lacked savoury or original flavours that would make you go back for specific dishes. 

The good:  Cacio e pepe is great- am I running back for it anytime, maybe. 
The disappointing: Avoid the Branzino (sea bass) if you have a problem with bones- they make no effort in deboning it before serving. 

The main issue here is service. It was exceptionally slow; had to call the staff several time for refills, orders, more wine, where's our food... etc. T
he timing between each course needed to be shortened but half if not more. I don't think they want you sitting there for 3 hours without dessert even. There were too many loooong pauses during meal staring at an empty table waiting for another round of dishes. 

With lots of great Italian options in the city I would definitely consider it more like a wine bar with a few nibbles rather than a full fledged hearty meal.

I'm putting this into the top 5 restaurants category in Toronto which is very high praise. Very impressed with the dining experience. Here's the breakdown:

Service (10/10) 
- excellent attention to detail. Informative, respectful, timely etc. They knew the menu well, they were able to explain how best to place an order which I find is often very under rated. Many servers don't do a great job of explaining this well. That wasn't an issue here. 

Ambiance (10/10) 
- modern, dimly lit and classy. Enjoyed the unique vibe and ambiance. Interesting lighting and set up with bae cart by the entrance. Washroom were very clean which is also a good reflection of how clean the restaurant and kitchen is likely to be. 

Food (9/10)
- high quality of food. We did 2 apps, split a pasta and meat dish. Best way to dine here is tapas style and to share everything. I could taste quality ingredients and very well executed overall. No issues with the food at all. Enjoyed it. 

Drink (7/10)
- this is the only area I feel they can work on. Cocktails weren't anything to rave about. Wine selection for by the glass wasn't great. Although their selection by the bottle was derailed. If they improve this they'll be taking major steps forward to best Italian restaurant in Toronto for sure. 

Price/value (8/10) 
- priced appropriately for the quality. No major concerns here. Overall great value and experience

Good date place. The atmosphere was phenomenal. The food good but for what you pay I think you can get something  more? The seafood pasta had salty clams, I think the clams they were using was naturally salty? But a little bit too salty to eat. 
Olive stuffed sausage was amazing. The tripe roman style was good but wish it was more flavourful. All in all great place. Service and cocktails were good as wel

My outlook improved when the burrata ($30) was set on the table. The cheese draped with thin slices of salty prosciutto, why mess with a great combination? 

Since the bread wasn't toasted or oiled, it was a bit chewy and difficult to get a knife through, so if it was cut thinner it would be even better. The caramelized onion and fig spread on the bread was absolutely delicious and went so nicely with the milky flavourful cheese, which was served at a perfect room temperature. The staggering $30 price tag was a bit of a surprise though... note to self, always ask for prices with specials.  

Well marbled beef was used in the carne cruda di chianina ($19) and while I couldn't taste the fried garlic mentioned on the menu, the anchovy was an interesting addition to the mix. We're asked if we'd like a side of bread ($3) which, in my opinion, is a must. You really need something to spread the beef tartare on or it'd be way too salty and overpowering on its own. For those that are abstaining from carbs, perhaps a salad would help balance the flavourful beef.

Even one of Giulietta's pizzas would be a great shared starter. The l'amentea ($21) has a healthy portion of spicy soppressata and tons of garlic that would give Count Dracula a scare. I love garlic so found it went nicely with the soppressata, but did drown out the fior di latte, which became more for its creamy chewy texture than flavour. The well blistered crust was coloured evenly and had a lovely chewy texture, but could be thicker in the middle as the paper-thin centre became lost amongst the sauce.

Had my bday dinner at the counter seating in front of the kitchen, a great spot to watch the chef cooking the dishes. Food was great except the pasta. It's raw, not Al dente. We ordered the octopus. The portion size of each piece has a quite big difference. Wonder if they give s bigger portion for a large table. As we only had two people, we ordered the pork chop instead of the porterhouse. It's lovely cooked with cheeky pink inside. The highlight was the dessert, pine nut tart with wildflower honey and vanilla mascarpone. It's not too sweet with balanced flavour. 
The kitchen gave us a piece of choco tarte as bday cake. It's funny that the candle light was off three times as it's windy above our seats. 
I'd love to try their pizza in the future. However I doubt if I will go again coz they don't seem like to chat with asians

I love the ambiance and service of this place! We came for a company dinner, and got seated at the window seat. The decor of this place is quite simple and minimalistic, and the lighting is minimal and very warm. There are these warm yellow tubes and lights hanging from the ceiling, with lighting coming from the chef's open kitchen / bar.

I got a mocktail drink, the albicocca. It was a nice light drink, slightly sweet from the apricot but also balanced with the sourness from the lemon. I pointed out a chip on my wine glass, and the waitress apologized profusely and immediately switched it out. She was super kind and attentive throughout dinner.

We shared a bunch of food, all of which were excellent:

Burrata Appetizer:
This appetizer was the special of the day. There was a ball of creamy burrata topped with prosciutto, both on top of a sourdough bread spread with sweet tapenade. The mash of textured was very interesting. The mild flavour of the burrata matched perfectly with the sweetness of the spread, balanced by the salty prosciutto. It's pretty good, but a fairly small piece. We split it among the four of us, and we each got a little over a bite.

Tomato Panzanella:
This appetizer came in a small bowl; the orange and red tomatoes were well-marinated in a basil olive oil mixture. The toasted bread was fairly interesting - the once crispy bread was a little soaked and soggy from the mixture. This was interesting, but not necessarily one of my favourites.

Radicchio di Castelfranco:
The slightly bitter radicchio was coated with a slightly sweet honey dressing, creating a lovely mixture and balance. I particularly enjoyed the sweetness of the soft bosc pears, juxtaposed against the crispness of the hazelnuts. I particularly enjoyed the hazelnuts and honey dressing!

Insalata Verde:
The bibb lettuce was cut rather largely and came in whole leaves. It was nice and soft, tossed evenly in the lemon vinaigrette. Since one member of our party is vegan, we got the parmesan on the side. To be honest, I found this salad quite overpriced.

Roasted Carrots:
Miniature, adorable orange carrots sliced in half arrived in another small plate (I'm seeing a trend with the sizes). The carrots were approximately the length of my thumb, and were quite sweet! Slightly oily, but still a classic side nonetheless.

Crispy Potatoes:
These potatoes were amazing and SO flavourful! I loved how the outside was super crispy and crunchy, with twigs of rosemary coating it all. So addicting... I had a ton!

Polpo e Fagioli:
This dish comes with a whole small octopus! The octopus is tender; it was probably boiled before, but definitely grilled after! There was a nice char to the ends, which made it quite crispy. It was plated on a creamy mixture of cannellini beans, and the salsa verde was a lovely addition. To be honest, I probably had all of this dish to myself... One colleague had perhaps a leg. No problem - I thoroughly enjoyed and savoured every minute of it!

Chestnut Agnolotti:
We got this, but omitted the guanciale. It was absolutely delicious! Perfectly creamy, and the ultimate comfort food. The agnolotti was bite sized, stuffed with a nice amount of chestnut mash. I thoroughly enjoyed the sprinkled cheese and occasional wilted green! We all raved about this dish, and this was definitely one highlight of the meal.

We also ordered two pizzas - I tried the L'Amatriciana. The crusts were super thin and there was a great char. I enjoyed the saltiness of the guanciale, though I did find it a little too fatty at times.

We then shared three desserts among us four - all were utterly delicious!

Cesta di Frutta:
A lemon and basil curd came within a baked meringue base, topped with candied berries (strawberries and blackberries). The meringue was fantastic! It was the perfect chewiness and crisp. I also enjoyed the tanginess of the curd, though the lemon flavour lingers and comes out mainly at the end. 

Lemon Crostata:
This was very similar to a lemon meringue pie - the lemon curd was heavenly! A classic comfort, and topped with a dollop creamy meringue.

Torta della Nonna:
Honestly, I didn't expect I'd enjoy this much, but I loved it! The honeyed pine nuts were glorious and so nutty and addicting. The tart base was also well executed, and the mascarpone cream balanced it all - the smoothness against the crispness of the tart, the mild flavour framing the sweetness and nuttiness. Would definitely get this again!

Our group of 7 were seated at 6pm for the early seating. We were told there's another party coming in at 8:30 so we got 2.5 hrs to dine and dash.  Personally, I don't mind the maître giving us the heads up, it allows everyone to be on the same page and respectful of others time it's really busy and our food takes extra long to come out.  

In terms of food, we ordered the seafood pasta, pepperoni pizza, fried seafood, roasted peppers, sweet corn, pork chop, carbonara and ravioli.  I ordered the seafood pasta, the noodles were perfectly cooked however the seafood wasn't the freshest specially the calamari.  The sweet corn was overly sweet, can almost be a dessert, not my cup of tea.  Aside from those two dishes, Everything else was really good. 

We didn't get a chance to order dessert because our mains took really long to come out and it was 8:15 by the time we finished. I would that that's another disappointment.  

Overall, I would say this place has great ambience, beautiful decor and super friendly staff.  It's worth checking it out.

I finally understand what all the buzz is about! I went here to grab some food for Mother's Day, and I'm so happy I did.

Lots of people waiting for their orders but the process is super thorough so it's not an unpleasant experience. You order online on their website and receive a time to pick-up. When you arrive they have an electronic screen with order names on it,  they also call out your name if it's ready. Super painless and efficient.

I ordered the tum yum soup appetizer, chicken pad thai, Massaman beef curry, and chicken panang curry. Everything was delicious. Other reviews were right to highlight how delicious the pad Thai and curries are. The spice level I chose was "medium" and it was just perfect. Could have done it a bit spicier but didn't want to chance it this time around.

The portions are not large but good for two people. It's definitely packed with flavour so you're paying for quality - not quantity. Definitely worth the higher end of prices for the tastiness of the food.

Highly recommend!

My boyfriend and I stopped in for lunch while visiting Toronto during the Corona outbreak. The ambiance was so nice, the staff were very friendly and the food......OMG The food was absolutely delicious!!! I had the Pad Thai and my boyfriend had the curry. Both were soooo flavorful and plentiful. We had the chicken satay for an app and that too was fabulous!!!! Pai Northern Thai Kitchen will not disappoint. As I'm writing this my boyfriend is currently ordering takeout for tonight since the dining room is closed.

I give this restaurant four stars. I have eaten food at Pai twice, most recently in late November 2019.

Pai is a trendy Thai restaurant located in downtown Toronto. It is one of the most popular spots in the city so you need to make a reservation in advance. It is busy and loud, and constantly has hip hop and pop music playing in the background. The majority of the guests are millennials so it might not be the best place for everyone.

The food is very good and very filling. I always order too much which is okay as the leftovers (excluding anything crispy) tend to travel well. There are a lot of menu options and you can't really go wrong with anything.

Highly recommended. I will be back soon. Four stars.

Great Thai food is really hard to come by.    This place is always busy, but the wait is not too bad.  I think we waited about 30 mins, but the food was well worth it.  We got the Squash fritter, Chicken Pad Thai, Massaman Curry and some drinks.  We enjoyed everything

Would come by here again

Bold flavours and a electric atmosphere make Pai a go to if you're craving Thai in Toronto. The dishes are full of flavour and the pleasant heat that comes with Northern Thai food specifically. The beef curry that I had was rich without being overpowering, and the Tom Yum soup was just the right balance of sour and spicy. 

I would definitely recommend going, but be sure to either make a reservation or be prepared to wait in line for a table. I went on a random weekday night and still needed to call a few days in advance for a table for four

I miss their Thai food there!
The curry and Tom yum soup are always two of the dishes that I always ordered! Must try if you loveeee Thai food! :)

Came across this restaurant while browsing food places closeby the DoubleTree hotel. It was about a 13 min walk and my boyfriend and I came at 9pm. We were thinking the crowd would die down by then but we were wrong. The restaurant was still packed. We were able to get seated quickly. 
I ordered the pad Thai and my boyfriend ordered the pad gra prow. I can't have spicy so I ordered no spice. You have the option of adjusting the spice level. My boyfriend got medium spice for his dish. He cleaned his plate good and ended up finishing mine. Portions were good for the price. Plates range starting from $15-16. Quality and flavors were there so it was a good meal. We loved the playlist they were playing and the ambiance. It was pretty loud in there with the music playing and the crowd, but we enjoyed our meal. Servers gave us great and fast service!

Went on a Sunday night and there was already a line. We got a table for two within five minutes. For a Thai restaurant, I would have to say this place has an unusual ambience -- it's dimly lit with popular North American songs blasting on speakers throughout the restaurant, and can be quite loud. There is also a full bar here if that's your thing.

All in all, the food was great. The Gaeng Kiaw Wan 'In a Coconut' is a green curry dish served with rice and extra green curry in a bowl on the side (the waiter said it was because it can't all fit in the coconut). It is a dish more on the spicy side, but I would say it's still manageable. The coconut really gives this dish some character, and you can also scoop out some coconut meat with your spoon to eat as well. You can choose between chicken, beef, dish, or tofu & veggies.

Khao Soi is also a curry dish but it is a coconut curry dish. It is more sweet than spicy but still has a kick of spice to it. I like the combination of egg noodles and crunchy noodles. We got braised beef chunks (like the ones you put in beef stew), but you can choose between chicken or beef. I thought this dish might be overhyped when I was reading Yelp reviews prior to coming here, but it really is worth the hype.

Highly recommend this place for anyone looking to have Thai food in Toronto. I'll definitely be back again.

Just went here for lunch.    Amazing food and great service.   Get here early or make sure to have a reservation, because this place gets busy (and for good reason).

Had the green curry with fish.   For $16 you get a ton of food.   Got about 5 pieces of delicious fish (Basa though, but I like the taste of Basa).   The fish is not over battered in its panko crust.    Fried to perfection and very juicy.  The curry sauce is so good which is served on the side.   I dipped the fish and poured some on my rice.   

Have to go back to try the Khao soi next time.   Can't wait to go back

Hip young Thai restaurant that meets or surpasses  the old school authentic Thai restaurant taste! Cool decor and atmosphere, played good music. Young waiters and waitresses. 

Accommodated us by seating us at the bar! They also had the option of traditional Thai floor seating. 

We were in a rush and opted to sit at the bar. The food was unreal!!!!!!!! 

We had a papaya salad for starters which we were hoping was spicy but literally had no spice factor at all. It was ehh...I have had better.

But the main dishes were top notch.

I ordered the Pad Gra Prow with chicken and I can not stop thinking about it. So delicious. The pad thai was also yummy. But the Pad Gra Prow was my absolute fav.

Atmosphere: 5
Cleanliness: 5
Quality: 5
Service: 5
Taste: 5

Couldn't secure a reservation during my visit to Toronto but they take walk-ins so that's what I did. The wait for a party of 2 on the evening (the day after new year) was estimated to be about 20 minutes but we were seated before that. 

For drinks I had the regular Thai tea and then later an alcohol version of Thai tea  featuring vodka (yea, you read that right!! IT was rather tasty!)

The spring rolls and tom yum soup were  our appetizers of choice. The rolls were fried with cabbage and mushrooms inside. The soup served with mushrooms and shrimp was flavorful and well balanced.

The khao soi and pad krapow were our entrées of choice. The pad krapow came out with the fried egg and rice and tasted as it should. And khao soi was truly excellent. The curry was  possibly one the best I've tasted .

Overall, Pai lived up to my expectations and to it's name. By the time we walked out, there was a line of people waiting to be seated that went around the block it seemed and when I saw that, I nodded in agreement. Worth the wait!

Pai has its fair share of rave reviews, and I have to agree for the most part. I've been 4-5 times before and it's always busy. There is ALWAYS a wait if you're going to walk in. We went on a Saturday night and surprisingly only waited 15 min for a table for 2. I've had to wait for over an hour during previous visits. Pai makes you feel like you're on a street in Thailand, experiencing their vibrant street foods. Service is casual and friendly - they are always super busy so I was satisfied with the level of attention from the wait staff. 

1) squash fritters - a crispy delicious finger food, served with a sweet and sour dipping sauce. I just found the fritters a little mushy towards the middle, I wish the whole fritter was as crispy as the edges. 
2) pad Thai - excellent!! One of the best pad Thais I've had, super balanced flavours and the medium spicy was perfect for us. 
3) green curry - served in a young coconut, I did not really enjoy this. The curry was watery and the chicken was very dry. The only part I enjoyed was scraping the coconut pulp out of the shell.

This place is definitely one of my favourite Thai restaurants in Toronto! The flavours are very authentic and I am still craving this now as I write this. Reservations are preferred, especially for a large group as this restaurant is extremely popular and crowded. The decor is very welcoming and unique, with vintage items on the walls and tables. I would recommend dining in the separate area in the back, as it is quite loud and may be too noisy for some. 

My favourite dishes are the pad gra prow (Basil Stir-Fry Beef with steamed jasmine rice) and the green curry that comes inside a coconut, which is a nice touch. I don't normally have a high spice tolerance, but the medium spice level was just right for me or it would be too bland otherwise. I also loved their Thai Iced Tea which was very rich and refreshing! Look forward to my next visit!

WOW!! Completely understand why this restaurant has such amazing reviews. We arrived here around 7:15pm and only waited 15 minutes before being seated. There's a designated area for those waiting for seating so customers aren't standing around the entrance. 

We ordered the spring rolls (vegetarian), Chef Nuit Pad Thai, and Khao Soi. For the dishes, you're able to select the level of spiciness as well. This was my first time trying Khao Soi at any thai restaurant and I was blown away! The broth was creamy and the dishes were all cooked and seasoned to perfection. 

Definitely one of our favorite meals in Toronto.

It's always Pai VS Khao San Road and I am Pai fan. I like their curries better and their pad thai is saucier and more flavourful than Khao San Road.

I would say that the line ups are ridiculous here considering how many years this place has been opened for so go early or go have a drink while you're waiting.

I'm really not sure why this place has such great reviews, I found the food merely average. The interior reminds me more of the Southeast Asia budget "backpacker" vibe, ie partiers. It's certainly a part of the Thai experience but not really my thing.

Tom yum soup - this was pretty solid with vibrant flavors and a good kick. Maybe I've really lost spice tolerance but I was starting to drip before I was done with the cup...

Pad cha hett - mushroom stir fry. I got this with black rice just to try something new and it didn't quite fit the rest of the dish. If you get this, stick with the jasmine. The stir fry part was disappointingly bland though. It had a bit of a fennel taste to it, not sure what that comes from.

THIS PLACE WAS SOOOOO GOOD! I was in Toronto for a women's conference and my friend and I decided to check this place out for dinner. We were promptly seated and given menus. She's a vegetarian and they had really nice options to choose from. I went with the pad Thai. We got our food and holy portions! I ate mine for dinner, a later meal before bed, then STILL had some left for the next day. My friend got the soup and also got 2 meals out of it. Service was great, location was great and priced very reasonable for downtown Toronto!

Food: A very popular place in downtown for thai food and it definitely did not disappoint me at all! I did not order pad thai (what I usually stick with) because I was trying to be more adventurous and I was very glad with my food choices! I highly recommend the pork rice with egg as it was the best out of three. Im guessing the pork was marinated with a lot of different ingredients and so with the fish sauce and lime juices, there was a burst of different flavours going on in a single bite. The chicken wings were amazing as well but nothing too surprising. The curry noodle was very interesting as I did not expect them to use egg noodle, the beef brisket was too hard though. I did still enjoy the coconut heavy flavoured curry overall. 

Portion: Normal to small

Environment: I was put to sit at a high table and the only issue was that there was no where to hang my winter jacket. Other than that the vibe of the restaurant was really nice with all the decors!

Came here on a Monday at lunch and it was really busy. I love the cool, hipster vibe of this place, it feels very casual, has really cool decor, theres a bar and overall it just feels comfortable.
We ordered the Papaya Salad which I really liked. The papaya is soaked in tamarind sauce giving it a sweet & sour taste, it came with flavourful shrimp chips, crispy pork grinds, some noodles and cabbage. Everything eaten together tastes so good! Definitely recommend!
I had the Masaman Beef Curry, at first the bowl looks kind of small but its actually very filling. They give you a lot of beef (perfect for meat lovers) and its very tender. The curry tastes like regular curry but with a hint of sweet&sour tamarind which I really liked.
My friend had the Khao Soi and to me it was just ok, it tastes like a regular coconut curry. Reminds me of a Malaysian Laksa.

It was alright. Went in here for lunch service and ordered the Khao soi.  I knew all the hype surrounding this restaurant. 

To be honest I don't understand why they are awarded with such accolades I stayed in Thailand for a month so I will use that for comparison. 

I find the Khao soi too rich and coconutty. It over takes the subtle nuances of a balanced dish. It just taste like coconut cream soup. I wouldn't make this the quintessential place for Thai food. Support other local businesses.

I never fully understood the taco genre but my life changed when I had the Baja fish taco. Best taco I've ever had in my life. I think of it often. 

I also had the Pulpo a la Mexicana (octopus), which was also good but I definitely don't love eating octopus in a taco. Biting into a taco with crispy fish is just more satisfying than something chewy, y'know?

A warning to those who are visiting for the first time, there is almost no sitting room in this place so be prepared to bring your tacos elsewhere to eat.

Love this place.

Ok, so I know this place is all the rage. 

I ordered the grilled beef for corona takeaway and I was disgusted. There was more fat, cartilage and inedible pieces than beef. Chew chew CRUNCH - spit. Over and over. My friend called me two hours later after ordering the same thing - she ended up giving her order to the homeless after the first bite. 

This means that they either don't clean (cut the meat) properly, or using cheaper pieces to save a buck. 

The grilled chicken was dry too. Honestly though, the shrimp was good. Stick to pulled beef and chicken for authenticity and - TEXTURE. C'mon seven lives!

Very disappointed.

This place is a small hole in the wall and worth visiting if you crave some good old fashioned tacos rather than the commercial stuff.. portion sizes were good however the flavours were slightly missing for me.. 

I would visit them again if I was in the area, but not necessarily my go to place. Please don't let my review deter you from trying their tacos though, they are still pretty good. 

Flavours can be very subjective and this place is definitely worth a try.. but if you know and love tacos and taco culture as much as me, then you would also know that everyone has their own go to spot.. 

This place has great service, friendly staff and a small seating area if you just want to eat quickly or grab'n'go.

CASH ONLY!!! & the location is kind of odd and the place is super tiny! But through it all the tacos are delicious....

All tacos are 6 bucks each. 

I ordered 2 tacos and was super full! I got the smoked marlin taco and the camarones a la diabla.

The camarones a la diabla was so fire!!! All the flavors were perfect. The marlin taco was not bad but a little on the drier side. Def would recommend the camarones a la diabla!

I tried the HOT salsa - and I like spicy but this was reallllly spicy! Good flavor tho but just an FYI for those daring souls.

I did not like that they didn't have small cups for salsa and you had to put your salsa straight on your taco. It's some what unsanitary from my perspective.

Came here before during my visit in Toronto and really enjoyed this place. There isn't much room to sit or eat, but they give you sauces and likes for your tacos. 
Food -
Cabeza : very tender meat and lots of sauce. Would definitely get it again.
The fish taco I had here was very good as well. 
The prices here are a little much but the quality of the food makes up for it. Definitely worth coming for a bite.

Knowing where to get the best tacos in town is serious business. As it stands, the best tacos that I have ever eaten have been at Tacofino in Tofino and Tres Carnales Taquería in Edmonton. After reading that Seven Lives was voted #1 Best Taco 2018 by NOW Toronto, named in National Geographic magazine's Places of a Lifetime article, and called #1 Best Fish Taco and #1 Best Tacos by blogTO... They seemed like a sure bet.

You'll find Seven Lives located in Kensington Market, one of the most eclectic corners of the city which suits them well. I visited the tiny shop on a Friday evening, prior to their early closing time of 7pm. They're definitely more of a lunch or early dinner type of place. It should also be noted that they accept cash only, so come prepared!

The tiny shop is bustling and exciting, buzzing with taco energy. The bright walls and giant sign that reads "TACOS" sets the vibe perfectly. I also appreciate their logo of a cat with a fish in its mouth - and the insinuation that this cat is down to seven lives, having already lost two. There is one table that can seat about four people and then there's a little bit of standing-room-only counter space. This makes things a little bit awkward if you plan to eat-in, as I did. The table wasn't available and so I stood at the counter in front of the window to eat instead. Which was fine. But certainly not ideal.

The menu is fairly straight forward, including nine types of tacos, some sides, and some beverages. Your order is placed at the counter with a friendly staff member and they call out your name once the food is ready.

Starting with something to drink, I was happy to see Agua de Jamaica on the menu. I always prefer an agua fresca when visiting a Mexican establishment, although I was also happy to see that Jarritos Mexican sodas are also on offer. (Their cola is my personal favourite of all of the colas.) Agua de Jamaica, otherwise known as "hibiscus water" is a beverage that exists in several cultures. In Southeast Asia it is known as Rosella tea and it's basically the same thing. Tart and sweet, this refreshing drink was a perfect accompaniment to the food.

We decided to get a Side as a bit of an appetizer. Tortilla Chips (Made fresh! - $3.00) and Guacamole ($3.00 for small) seemed like the way to go. I was a bit surprised that the guacamole didn't just come with tortilla chips and that both items had to be purchased separately. However, I did enjoy the homemade nature of the chips and that a heaping amount of them are tossed into a brown paper bag and given to you. I'll take a bag of chips any day. Golden and ultra crispy, these tortilla chips are exactly what I wanted them to be. They were seasoned really nicely as well. The guacamole was fresh and bright, with a great acidic kick to it. Obviously chips and guac are a match made in heaven.

Next it was time for the big show: the TACOS. Of the nine tacos available, two of them (the Adobada and the Carnitas) were already sold out. On the plus side, I probably wouldn't have ordered either of these anyway. Although, I must say that this did not leave much for meat options. There were four fish/seafood tacos, one beef and one chicken option, and a vegetarian. Nothing for pork at all. But again, I did not mind at all because I was going full ocean food - it's what they specialize in, after all.

Baja Fish ($6.00) and Gobernador ($6.00) were the ones for me. I loved the little condiments bar to the left of the counter that featured three different salsas (hot habanero, medium tomatillo, mild guajillo) as well as chili oil with sesame, and a bowl of sliced limes. This makes it very easy to customize your tacos to your preferred specifications and to control the amount of heat that you desire.

The tacos did not take very long and before I knew it, a green plastic basket was placed in my hands. The tacos were certainly vibrant and demanding to be eaten.

I began with the Gobernador (smoked marlin, shrimp & cheese). If Seven Lives has a signature taco, this is the one. Their front window even says "home of the Gobernador" right on it. I definitely loved the smokiness from the marlin the most, while the shrimp filled out the taco and added more texture. Everything had been grilled up deliciously. The pickled onion brought a great hit of balancing flavour and I liked the fresh tortillas a lot.

Next I had the Baja Fish (fried haddock). The first thing that I noticed is how generous the portion of fish is! The haddock was big, juicy and fried to perfection. The rest of the taco was kept very fresh with cabbage and fresh homemade salsa on top.

Both tacos were packed full and were pretty messy to eat, but in the best possible way. I liked both tacos but found them to be missing something that I can't quite put my finger on. I guess that I was hoping for something even bigger and more unexpected in terms of flavour. They were good... Just not the best that I've ever had.

I was also very impressed to see a C

We were extremely excited to try this taco spot during our stay in Toronto. Unfortunately, everything was sold out when we arrived the first day. Lucky for us, we were there for the first "Pedestrian Sunday" of the year. The street is closed off and many restaurants bring their business on the streets with stands. 

The tacos were a lot bigger than I imagined! They're a little on the pricier side but so worth it. They also have four sauces on the side with different spice levels - mild, medium, hot and Mexican hot. 

Cash only spot, please come prepared!

Wow, the most intense tacos I've ever had! Don't go expecting to have a sit down meal and please do yourself a favour and don't go on a date here because you will get messy. I promise you it's all worth it.

Wait in line and order at the cash, wait for your tacos and hope there's a seat. We were there at 3pm on a Saturday and we managed to squeeze in at the bar table. You can always take out but I think dining there is also part of the experience. 

The tacos are massive! I thought 2 wouldn't be enough but it was more than enough. They also have many different hot sauces you can add. Never have I eaten tacos with a fork but trust me, these are very big and I had to eat half the inside before I was able to somewhat grab them.

I believe they're opening a larger location across the street, I think it's much needed to keep up with the demand!

My cousin loves this taco place and highly recommended us to come here for our 2nd food adventure. We ordered the octopus taco and the grilled swordfish taco. Each taco was able $6ish, which is really pricey for a taco. I am used to getting tacos for $3-4ish in San Francisco, so these $6ish tacos better be delicious.

Octopus taco (5/5) - For any octopus lovers here, I highly recommend this taco. I've never had octopus tacos before and this was super delicious. You know that the octopus is fresh when you see an employee pulling the octopus with a large strainer out of a bucket. 

Grilled swordfish taco (5/5) - I don't eat swordfish often, but when I took a bite of this taco, I thought the fish tasted like meat. This was pretty good too.

This shop is really small. They provide different levels of hot sauce on the counter, along with some wet wipes. This place is CASH ONLY, so make sure to bring enough cash. The tacos are on the pricier end, but definitely worth it!

I always had this place tucked away in my Yelp bookmarks but never made it until now. I dropped by with a friend for a snack after Christmas Market and it definitely lived up to it's wonderful reviews!

The restaurant is in the heart of Kensington Market and is pretty small. Only one table that fits about 6 and a bar area where you could stand. I got Gobernador and it was SO GOOD. I feel like this was also enhanced by the fact that we were starving since we are directionally challenged and spent about 15 minutes getting lost before finding the place ...

They were very generous with the toppings, lots of cheese, shrimp, and marlin. Everything was enveloped by two taco shells the outer one was crispier and the inner was soft providing a nice contrast.

When I tell you I have truly nothing bad to say about this place I truly mean it . This place is one of my favorite tacos and yes it's all the way in Canada !! These tacos taste so authentic, fresh and are made to order. We also got chips and salsa which was were tasty as well ! 
I tried the shrimp, carnitas and carne asada !! Believe it or not my favorite was the shrimp !! The sauce was incredible! Definitely a little messy but honestly just grab some chips and pick up what was left behind.
Loved this place !!

Special tacos are $6, which is more expensive than I am used to spending on tacos but you are also paying for unique, higher quality tacos. We had the Baja Fish and Carnitas tacos and they were delicious. Definitely a must-try place in Toronto.

Like many places in Kensington, the place is quite small and there aren't many seats. Be prepared to either stand at their standing tables or stand outside and eat. We stood at one of the standing tables which was fine because it doesn't take long to consume their delicious tacos.

Visit: Saturday inthe 5 o'clock hour 

Atmosphere: small shop,minimal seating only one uneven bench and only uneven table lol busy but organized line moves at a decent pace 

Food: I got 2 tacos $6 each, all tacos are the same price. I got the fried haddock and the beef... the beef was so tender and literally melted in my mouth the sauce that they but on it paired well with it. The haddock wow what a large portion the fillet was bigger than my tortilla that never happens the tartar sauce was yummy and went great with the diced tomatoes. Both tacos were hot temperature wise and served fresh

I would recommend and I will go back next time I'm in the area to try the other combinations

Pros:
1. The shrimp & cheese taco (only 1 taco...) is delicious.
2. The taco finishes with a layer of cheese and pickled onion, quite guilty :) 
3. And a layer of meat at the bottom!

Cons:
1.long lineup 
2. $2 higher than other places in Kensington Market.

All you want in a tacos street style stop! 

Small place, too crowded, mexican deco a bit modernized, not much place to eat....


But but but.  The best tacos i had in my life! 

Try the cabeza really amazing and a bit spicy
the carnita more classic but really good
And the pulpo a la mexicans was also amazing. 

A must stop in visiting Toronto

4 stars for taste
2 stars for price 
Which really should be a 3, but the meat is just so delicious. Coming from LA, I just don't think I can justify 6 CAD for ONE taco and one alone!! If you expect to be full, get ready to spend 20 CAD per person (and really that's like 3 tacos plus tax). 

With price aside, the taste is absolutely delicious. I tried the Pollo Asado and Carnitas- the chicken taco was so tender and the dressing was creamy, dressed with carrots. The carnitas was more no frills - meat with a salsa. 

There's a salsa bar on the side and limited seating, one bench table and the rest is counter space along the window.

They have never let me down. Their tacos has consistently been the best I've had in Toronto. Always fresh, always delicious. I always bring visitors to this joint because it's such a good reflection of the food, culture, environment of Toronto. 

Tried their beef cheeks for the first time and my goodness, I don't know why it took me so long! It was absolutely heavenly. Definitely recommend!

I expected to experience a lot of exceptional food while in Toronto for a few days, but being from Southern California I most certainly did not expect to have one of the best contemporary tacos of my life. That's exactly what happened, and everything I thought I knew about Seafood tacos has been shaken. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

Seven Lives is a somewhat cramped little shop that's cash only and is prone to both overheating and overcrowding in the Summer. Typically, that's a recipe for disaster as far as service and atmosphere are concerned, but the chaos builds on the hype a bit to be honest and it's all good in my mind given Seven Lives actually delivers on their widespread and now long-standing hype. Hunker down, have your cash ready, and you can expect your tacos in between ten and fifteen minutes after ordering. Until then just sit back and watch them work their magic. Star. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

$6.00 per taco is expensive, plain and simple even with a generous rate of exchange to the USD these days. Even so, the tacos at Seven Lives are at least two to even three times larger than your standard street taco and are jam packed with all sorts of different fillings, which makes the price point worth it. Star. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

For the purposes of emphasis, I'm going to set aside what was an exceptional Spicy Chicken taco in its own right just to focus in on the real prize here, which is and was the Gobernador taco. 

Smoked Marlin, Shrimp, Cheese, spices, house made fiery habanero sauce. This was so unexpected, so exceptional, so life-changing that I didn't even know what to do with myself. This was, I think it's fair to say, the very best seafood taco I've ever had in my entire life, and that's after having visited at least fifty or so seafood taco spots across the United States. Amazing. Two Stars. 

Star 5: Would you be excited to go back?

High Praise for Seven Lives. I read in an interview that at one point the chef had deliberated between opening a shop in Toronto versus Southern California - my vote goes to both. Star.

These tacosssss. Hello. Still dreaming about them.

Is this a teeny tiny place? Yes. Is it extremely hot and muggy in here? Yes. Will you wait for a ridiculous amount of time in a lineup outside? Yes. BUT IT'S WORTH IT. Look, I'll wait all day for a good taco. I don't even care.

I tried the carnitas taco and the beef taco. Both were phenomenal and I'm just gonna make a bold statement - these were some of the best tacos I've ever had. The beef taco in particular was a stand out. The meat was so tender that it practically melted in my mouth, and the flavors were an absolute explosion of deliciousness. I love how they pile fresh cilantro on these babies. There's also a supplemental sauce station (in addition to what's already on the taco when it's handed to you), but I just went for a squeeze of fresh lime and that was all I needed.

Be aware that Seven Lives is cash only, but there's an ATM right across the street, so no worries there. Prepare to be amazed. This place is the one. Hallelujah, praise be to the taco gods.

My friend recommended this place. I was a bit skeptical at first, since I just went to San Diego not long ago and ate a lot of good tacos. I gave it a shot when my boyfriend and I passed by Kensington market. Although a bit iffy at the $6 price, we decided the line was a good indicator that the tacos were good.

This place is cash only, and we waited in line for 20 minutes or so. The line moves fairly quickly. We got the fish taco and one of the shrimp tacos - the fish taco was definitely the best I've had. The shrimp one was also good, but not as good as the fish taco.

Really wish we ordered more!

I would share this, but I'm too shellfish 
.
CHEEEESY baked oysters with spinach, mushrooms, and garlic mayo   
5/5
Incredibly delicious  I can rarely order this dish from Kinka Izakaya because THEY ALWAYS RUN OUT! Located at the heart of Toronto, this authentic Japanese restaurant is super fun, loud, and welcoming! It's the perfect spot to let loose and chill with friends! oishiiiii~

Take advantage of the 30% off promo they have on all takeout orders and order now!

Absolutely loved this spot when I went with friends on vacation in Toronto. I love Japanese izakaya spots because it's always fun to share the dishes and it's usually a lot of unique tapas. The menu has a nice variety to choose from, including the drinks. This is a long overdue review so I don't remember all the things we got. However, I do remember we got the fried shrimp, karaage, pressed salmon sushi, yaki udon, kalbi and more. They were all packed with flavor and very delicious! The portions can be a little small for its price but the experience and how the food actually tasted made up for it. For 4 people, we split about 8 dishes. We were decently full but could have ordered more.  

The atmosphere inside is so lively! For birthdays, they take a free polaroid for your party! I thought that was so cute. There were a lot of parties doing sake bombs as well. Whenever I'm back in Toronto, I'd definitely hit up this spot again. I highly recommend!

My friend got the lunch set which includes a don, salad, some takoyaki and kaarage, sashimi, and miso soup. I believe it was around $18 which is an amazing deal for the amount of variety you get! 

I got the kaarage don, which I have raved about so many times before. Kinka consistently serves fresh food that is full of flavour at an amazing price. It's my favourite izakaya and I will continue to go here again and again!

One of the oldest restaurants that I had been to. Since North York. It's always been a great experience with them! No matter was the lunch hours having great lunch sets and yummy fish; but also the dinner are always pretty impressive. The late snacks are pretty good too! 
Don't forget to try their cocktails if you drink! 
Overall a pretty good experience there although sometimes is too noisy to talk with frds

I've spent multiple birthdays here & the atmosphere is absolutely fantastic! 
The entire staff Cheers & greets you when you come in, the vibe is awesome and so is the food!

I love this restaurant! The atmosphere is lively, the staff are friendly, the food is fresh and delicious!

I've been here a few times now with varying groups of friends. I have to say, all have found it to be a very pleasant experience.

By this point, I've pretty much ordered everything on the menu at least once. The menu does not have a grand selection, and the portions are more less Japanese tapa-style. Great to share. You really can't go wrong with anything, but I particularly liked the udon (I know.. of all things, it's actually the best udon I've had in a while!). Of course, you also HAVE to (like MUST!!) order the sake bombs. When the sake bombs come, the restaurant chants with you and you pound your hands on the table until the shot drops into the beer cup. You then chug it (it's easy to go down, no worries).

Honestly such a fun experience. A great place to go with friends!

Heard a lot of hype about Kinka from friends who've been here previously and I wanted to love it but the volume level and food ultimately is what makes me give this place 3 stars. 

It's ABSURDLY loud, can't hear the person next to you talking; get ready to scream your order out. Most of the food was fine to not good but some of the things that I did find pretty delicious was the buta kakuni, miso black cod (albeit way too bones), and the yaki udon.

The karrage had too much batter and was hella dry, salmon oshizushi was bland, takoyaki and okonomiyaki was really w/e.

Basically I've had the same dishes better and at a reasonable volume at other places. Kinka is ultimately a turn up spot and if you treat it as such you won't be disappointed.

For a party of 3, we ordered 3 set meals and 2 drinks, and we left with our stomachs pretty full. This is my 3rd time at this location, but unfortunately stars were docked off for quite an uncomfortable experience. 

Made a reservation for a party of 3 for 6:30pm on a Tuesday, what we were given was a small table for 2 with a small stool at the side of our table, with my back to the adjacent customers table at a corner, which essentially felt like I was in the middle of the walkway. Throughout the entire dinner, I had felt extremely awkward and uncomfortable as I had felt the waiters/waitresses' bodies touching mine every time they came by to serve food to the table behind me. We've requested 2 times, when the restaurant was not packed for a larger table, but nothing was to be done. Unsurprisingly, I felt like we were being rushed in finishing our plates one right after the other as there were no room at all to fit any dishes anymore. 

If we had proper seating and space, I believe the experience would have been that much greater.

The gyudon set was great! Has everything we need. $18 for 6 different types of small dishes but overall it's totally enough. The gyudon was sooooo good. 

The staff are very energetic and the service was great. The restaurant became crowded after 12:15pm. (We came around 11:50am and there was no one). If you wanna avoid the rush on weekdays, better come before 12pm.

Such an amazing place! Everything on the food menu is  good. There is no bad item on it. My favourite is the pumpkin croquette. The items are small portions good to split about 2 people per plate, so it gives you a chance to try a variety of dishes. The servers are very nice and I love that they all greet you when you enter/exit. Food comes out very fast and prices are good. Always a good place to go.

My family and I came here with a party of 20 to celebrate our cousins bday. We left extremely full and a lil tipsy. This is your authentic izakaya with traditional seating , plenty of skewers and an extensive beverage menu. Most of our table decided to opt for the more expensive set menu. We love the beef carpaccio, kinoko bibimbap and the grilled miso black cod were a must try. Flavors were definitely very filling and packed with plenty of flavor. Texture wise the set menu is a great sampler to try all of their signature dishes. 
The samurai sake bombs are a must order if you want your bang for your buck for just 1 bomb. Save room for dessert as well as the black sesame or matcha ice cream are a must order. Overall we really enjoyed our experience and the food was superb. We had many picky eaters in the party but Kinka was able to accommodate all is!
Service is always awesome even when they have a full house. The variety in dishes is also top notch. Not so close to my office, unfortunately.

I've been here multiple times and always had a great time. This time, we decided to sit outside. Their seating for two people is very small and you don't have much space between the tables beside yours so it can feel a little cramped. 

This time, we decided to try their Kinkcalious which consists of eight small courses. The food was really good and I'm glad the baked oysters were one of the dishes because that's my favorite dish here! The rapini veggies tasted a bit weird to me but overall the dishes were good. Service was a bit slow outside in their patio and the waiters don't really pay a lot of attention to the diners because there were a lot of times where I tried to call out to them or get their attention and they just weren't looking in my direction. Overall, good food and okay service.

THE FOOD IS VERY GOOD!
The experience that I had there was amazing. As a Japanese, I always miss Japanese food and the atmosphere of Japanese izakaya. This place gave me a flash-back of my memories of Japan. The food that you can get there is indeed very authentic. The atmosphere was also like real-Japanese izakaya-style where the servers are very energetic and cheering. The communication can be a little bit hard since they are real Japanese whose English isn't the best, but it wouldn't bother you. Overall, this place offers you a good izakaya experience! As expected, the price isn't low, however, I could understand based on their food and service. If you really want to enjoy the great atmosphere of a Japanese izakaya, this place may be a good place to try!

This izakaya place is very popular, so I highly recommend to make reservation in advance. The food were good. The portion was small, so it is a good way to try various dishes. But I definitely enjoyed the drinks more. I personally prefer fruity drinks, and there were a lot of options. The restaurant also had special cocktail menu, and I LOVED the Yuzu Mitsu High one. The prices were reasonable, and the service was good. The only thing I didn't enjoy much was that the restaurant was really loud, and it was hard to chat with the friends. But overall I still had a good time!

Kinka Izakaya has a set menu Kinkalicious during Summerlicious!
It has 8 courses and serves 2(need 2 people to order). It's actually quite filling and is a great way to try many of their best dishes! Beef yukke is probably my favorite!

It's super loud in the restaurant which is a great Japanese izakaya experience. But probably not for people who are planning to have a quiet time there.

Wow! So many awesome surprises, from the garlic chips on the salad to the marinated octopus wasabi! Everything was fresh and innovative. We got the salmon tataki, sashimi salad, gomaae (rapini with black sesame seed) and tako wasabi. The rapini was awesome and tasted like nasu dengaku, even though rapini doesn't taste like eggplant, obv. They provided nori strips to make your own sushi rolls with whatever you've ordered, which is perfect for me because I like to put the veggies into sushi, but don't eat rice. The only thing I would not do is order seared fish to go because it doesn't arrive fast enough to be fresh. Get sashimi not seared for takeaway. 

I was happy with salad and rapini, while my friend was happy with the sashimi. I made a marinade of coconut vinegar, habanero sauce, garlic and coconut aminos for the sashimi as it was seared, it was starting to smell like fish. 

They provided soy sauce and wasabi mayo. 

This was a really fresh and new treat for tavern style Japanese! I was so excited I started eating with the wrong end of the chopsticks.

Not from the area but absolutely enjoyed my lunch here! I wish I was able to visit again to try the dinner tapas portion. 

Lunch options weren't a lot, but my lunch set tasted so good! Also the place radiates terrace house vibes...

I decided to try this japanese spot when visiting Toronto on a Thursday evening, and was surprised to find it quite lively and packed at 10pm. The servers were shouting some crazy stuff when serving certain dishes, and it all felt very lively. If your looking for a quiet place to eat, this definitely is not the spot, but I liked it. The service wasn't very quick, but the enjoyment made up for it. 

I ordered the Salmon Foil Yaki ($13) and Pork Steak ($9). The salmon came with grilled onions and mushrooms in a nice soy sauce mixture, and the fish was cooked very well. Each bite was juicy and it was soft to cut but still held firm together. The pork steak was my favorite though as it was a fatty flavory cut of pork with a sudbtle mustard sauce with some rice crisps, green onions, and lettuce on the side.

I couldn't help but smile when eating at this place. The food was very delicious, and cooked very well. I am usually not impressed with japanese style late night drinking/food spots (Izakaya), but this has been my favorite, and I've been to quite a few in Vancouver. Would be happy to bring a crew of people here again.

As soon as you walk in, you're greeted loudly by all the staff shouting "irasshaimase!" (welcome in Japanese) The seating is large tables that you share or seats along the bar. The music is loud and people are loud, but that's expected of an izakaya/bar and it was pretty fun to watch people downing sake bombs. The music selection was also awesome! Even asked for the playlist afterwards :)

Ok moving onto the food. The food was SO GOOD! I'm definitely a meat lover over a veggie lover , but the vegetable appetizer I ordered was delicious. It had a deep, smoky flavor and was seasoned well. Same goes for the yaki udon. The mackerel sushi was lightly blow torched and didn't have a fishy taste. The desserts were also excellent. I HIGHLY recommend the black sesame ice cream for those that like that flavor. Tasted like straight up frozen black sesame seeds (in the best way possible). I had a great time here and would go again if I'm visiting Toronto! Great food, atmosphere, and service.

Yum yum. They are open during covid times. Pork belly bao.... allll the way!!!!!!! Tastes the same every time so the consistency is there. Service is very casual and run by a young group of people, don't expect smiley hellos how are yous, just walk up to the counter and say what you want lol. Their papaya salad is like the pickled carrot and radish but with an extra veg (papaya) and some dressing- it was good! Crunchy and sauce was sweet but tangy. Tried sweet potato fries for the first time and no complaints - crispy, hot. They don't have spicy mayo but will give you mayo and sriracha on the side to mix yourself. Considering they use two small containers for mayo and sriracha, why don't they just combine it in a big batch, then upcharge $1 for spicy mayo? It's easier for staff to do in big batches and have them pre-filled in containers, than for the customers who have to open both sauces up, ask for a spoon, mix it up in the container, then throw out the extra container! Nobody wants to do that while their fries are getting colder by the second! So why not offer it on their menu? It's a staple sauce for sweet potato fries and it would be a great sauce option for all baos and sandwiches. Just a thought, management! Love everything about your concept and would love to have you guys in Mississauga. [franchise? ;)]

I've been coming here for years and the food never disappoints. I really enjoy their grilled pork banh mi. I normally ask for less carrots and cucumbers because they stack it well lol.

The sauce is really tasty, the produce used is very fresh and the meat is cooked well. 

I just went today and continuously, the staff are friendly and the service is fast. The quality of their food has not changed since opening up other locations which is always a plus.

Definitely worth a visit!

you have to try kalbi beef, either taco or sandwich or maybe bao (haven't try this yet) it is really good. 
Kimchi poutine is also very very good. 
I feel the sandwich bun is a little bit hard for me, but it's is Vietnamese style  for sure. 
Steam bao is also a good option, very soft bun. 
over all, definitely will  go back whenever i have time and chances.

I really want to like this place. I really do. I've gone here since 2013, and then I tell myself never again, but it's so close and convenient, etc. But yeah, everytime I go I wonder why it's rated so high by everyone else.

First, banh mi shouldn't take forever to make. Go to any Vietnamese place and the person behind the counter will literally slap together a sandwich in a matter of minutes. They have a team of people working here and it still takes longer somehow.

Second, the banh mi itself (i.e., the bread) doesn't taste right. It's not crunchy on the outside, soft in the middle. As for the rest of the sandwich, there's something about it that lacks authenticity. Atop of this, it's way pricier than it should be.

We had a quick bite at Banh Mi Boys as it was conveniently located near our hotel.  The menu is a decent size, and you purchase the Banh Mi sandwiches separate from the sides.  The prices are okay for the portion, however it would be nice if the sandwiches came with a little more of the vegetable slaw toppings, as the bun to topping ratio was a little much.  Our sandwiches came out quickly and were warm.  

We tried one each; I went with the Spicy Pork Belly Banh Mi, and my significant other chose the Squid.  My sandwich was really good; the flavors were fresh and delicious.  I went with the medium spicy, which was a spicy sauce.  It was just enough spice for me.  I would have liked to see more of the slaw/toppings on the sandwich.  My significant other's Squid Banh Mi was also very good, and he went with the spicy option of adding jalapenos.  He also wished for a little more of the toppings.   

Banh Mi Boys was good for a quick counter service option to dine in or take out.  My only issue was probably the cleanliness of the place; there was food on the floors and crumbs on the tables, and the garbage was overflowing.  The kitchen looked clean and our food was good, but with the lack of cleanliness in the dining area, it was hard not to feel a little put off.
Great Vietnamese sandwich place. It's not that unhealthy like usual fast food and it's really delicious as well. Got a couple sandwiches when I last visited and both were perfect.

I always like to drop by Banh Mi Boys when I am in the mood for some cheap eats! My go-to is the Kimchi Fries, which is like the Asian fusion version of the poutine. It's filling and great for under $10, especially if you feel like something from Smoke's would be too heavy for you.

Wowww this spot has some GOOD banh mi sandwiches.

Stopped by right after they opened on a Sunday and there were already people eating. Small spot designed mostly for take out, but there is some seating. Our group each bought a bahn mi and some sides, including fries and some boas 
I like traditional/standard banh mi sandwiches. Banh mi boys goes well beyond traditional and had some very interesting options, including the kabli beef which I got. It combined the traditional ingredients of a banh mi with Korean style beef... delicious. The sandwiches are quite large so don't feel like you need a lot of sides, or maybe share a sandwich and some sides.
We also spit some kimchi fries, which are truly LOADED, with fries, poutine, kimchi, bbq style meat and more. The portion is massive. They are delicious and loaded with tons of ingredients.

Can't belive I haven't rated the original Banh Mi Boys.. its so good! Lots of fresh fun things like Banh Mis, Kimchi Fries and Baos. Last time I was here we had to order everything. So much food! 

Real taste of Toronto/ LA

I came here under the recommendation of a friend. I was honestly so hungry but for a decent price, I got an appetizer (kimchi fries) that were shared between three people, and a delicious fried chicken Bao, that filled me right up. 

The service was great and the wait time wasn't bad. There are tables so you can sit and chat while you eat your food.

Highly recommend! I will be back again!

AMAZING Vietnamese Sandwiches!!!!
AMAZING Vietnamese Sandwiches!!!

This stop was pre-planned for our trip to Toronto based on the awesome reviews and I wanted to have different cuisines while in town. When we arrived in Toronto, this was our first stop for a quick bite. but I was lucky that the parking we found was walking distance to the GEM!. 

It's a boutique restaurant franchise with limited seating and people tend to order, sit and eat if there's available seats and then leave. We were lucky to get seats as it was a busy Friday afternoon. 

I could tell my sisters were skeptical about the cuisine based on their facial expressions cause they never had this before. We ended up ordering a 5 spice pork belly, grilled chicken sandwiches, a grilled chicken Taco and fried chicken Bao. Everything was delicious from there reaction.
They were really impressed by taste and crunchiness of pickled toppings paired with the sauce. The pickled carrots and cucumbers really enhanced the flavor in these sandwiches. All I heard after that was "hmmmmm this is good

Not authentic!! It's a good sandwich with good fillings. The bread however, is what makes a Banh mi a Banh mi and it was too soggy. Really good Banh mi bread is just perfect crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. This is not it. The fries were okay as well. Also too soggy. Sigh.

Solid. I always get the grilled pork banh mi, and am always happy with my choice.

There are 3 levels of heat to choose from - sriracha, jalapeño, habañero. Having gone the jalapeño route a few times and finding there wasn't enough heat, I got the habañero and found there was way too much. You never know what a batch of peppers is going to be like on a given day, which keeps things exciting. Now I go for "extra" jalapeño... which is often just the perfect amount of too much.

If it's sunny out, my banh mi boy and me like to order in, but take our order out to a nearby park to eat. The meat is warm, the sandwich well constructed and well wrapped (a cute little elastic band holds it all together)... and the fresh, grilled bun makes it all come together. Orders come up pretty fast here, and the price cannot be beat. I wish there was a location in Queen West.

Probably some of the most tasty food we had all weekend!! We walked about 6 miles to go to a comic book shop and decided we needed a snack. We ordered a 5 spice pork belly bao and a squid taco and headed back to our hotel. I noticed right away my bag was pretty heavy for only having two items and the smell coming from the bag was heavenly. Once we got to our room, hubby and I shared our "snack". OMG!! I'm so so sad wE didn't order more! We argued about which was better- I say squid, he says bao. Either which way, whEn we return for a concert in May- we'll come better prepared and more aware and definitely order more!
